title: Practice Quizz - Probability
text:
Some questions below will require you to do calculations. Enter only the numeric result in the answer field.


Which are good practice habits when using probability in ecology? Select all that apply.

Assume everything is independent to simplifyDefine events clearly before calculating probabilitiesAvoid assuming independence without justificationUse complements/unions to avoid double-counting



Good practice is conceptual: define events, choose the correct rule, and justify assumptions. Unjustified independence can badly mislead inference.




During a salmon count, 12 of 48 fish are Chinook salmon. Estimate P(Chinook) using relative frequency.



Relative frequency estimate is count / total = 12 / 48 = 0.25. This is an empirical estimate that would stabilize with larger samples.




Given P(A | B) = 0.30 and P(B) = 0.20, compute P(A ∩ B).



Multiplication rule: P(A ∩ B) = P(A|B)P(B) = 0.30 × 0.20 = 0.06.




If P(A ∪ B) = 1, compute P((A ∪ B)ᶜ).



If union covers the whole sample space (i.e., P(A ∪ B) = 1), its complement is impossible, so P((A ∪ B)ᶜ) = 0.




What do we call the set of all possible outcomes?



The sample space contains all possible outcomes for the process you are modeling (e.g., {detected, not detected} for one sample).




If A and B are mutually exclusive and both have positive probability, which are true? Select all that apply.

P(A ∩ B) = 0A and B cannot be independentP(A | B) = P(A)P(A ∪ B) = P(A) + P(B)



Disjoint events have zero overlap and additive union. With positive probabilities, independence would require P(A ∩ B) = P(A)P(B) > 0, which contradicts the fact that disjoint events have no overlap; so they cannot be independent. P(A | B) must be 0 if B occurs because A and B are disjoint.




If P(A) = 1, compute P(Aᶜ).



A is a certain event, so complement impossible: P(Aᶜ) = 1 − P(A) = 1 - 1 = 0.




In an ecological sampling scenario, P(A) = P(detect sample 1) = 0.4 and P(B) = P(detect sample 2) = 0.4. Assuming independence, compute P(detect in both samples).



Under independence: P(A ∩ B) = 0.4 × 0.4 = 0.16. In practice, subsequent sampling events may be dependent, but the arithmetic illustrates the product rule.




What is the term for ‘not A’?



The complement of A (or Aᶜ), is the event that A does not occur.




Two events are independent if:

They cannot occur togetherKnowing one occurred gives no information about the otherTheir probabilities sum to 1They have equal probability



Independence is about no change in probability when you learn information: P(A | B) = P(A). Independent events can co‑occur; it is mutually exclusive events that cannot. Equal probabilities or summing to 1 are not definitions of independence.




Which statements about “AND” vs “OR” are correct? Select all that apply.

A ∩ B means A AND BA ∪ B excludes cases where both occurA ∪ B means A OR B (inclusive)A ∩ B is always larger than A



Intersection is AND. Union is inclusive OR (A, B, or both). Union does not exclude overlap. Intersection is a subset of A, so it cannot be larger than A.




What word indicates conditioning in a probability statement?



The word given signals conditional probability, like P(A | B) = probability of A given B.




In a bird point-count, P(detect) = 0.65. Compute P(not detect).



Use complement rule: 1 − 0.65 = 0.35.




In a bird point-count, wind reduces detectability. Let A = “species detected”, B = “windy”. Which statements are plausible? Select all that apply.

A and B may be dependentThis automatically proves the species is absent when windyP(A | B) < P(A)P(A | B) must equal P(A)



Wind can make birds harder to hear/see, reducing detection probability. That means P(detect | windy) can be lower than overall P(detect), indicating dependence. But lower detection does not prove absence. Instead, it reflects the observation process.




A stream dries during summer (event A) and juvenile salmon experience mortality (event B). Which statements are reasonable? Select all that apply.

If A occurs, B may become more likelyKnowing B occurred could provide information about whether A occurredA and B are likely dependentA and B are certainly independent



Drying reduces habitat and can increase stress, crowding, and predation risk, so mortality may become more likely. That is dependence: learning A changes beliefs about B and vice‑versa. Independence is not automatic and it must be justified.




You know P(A) = 0.3, P(B) = 0.7, and P(A ∩ B) = 0.4. Which statement is correct?

P(A | B) = 0.4P(A ∪ B) = 0.6A and B are mutually exclusiveA and B are independent because 0.3 × 0.7 = 0.21



Compute the union using the addition rule: P(A ∪ B) = P(A) + P(B) − P(A ∩ B) = 0.3 + 0.7 − 0.4 = 0.6. They are not mutually exclusive (intersection is not 0). They are not independent (0.3 × 0.7 = 0.21, not 0.4). Also P(A | B) = 0.4 / 0.7 = 0.57, not 0.4.




If P(A | B) ≠ P(A), what is the relationship between A and B?



If conditioning on B changes the probability of A, then A and B are dependent (associated).




A researcher says: “Because two events happen on different days, they must be independent.” What is the best response?

Correct — independence only depends on sample sizeIt depends only on whether events are rareCorrect — different days guarantees independenceIncorrect — independence is an assumption; shared drivers (e.g., environmentalc conditons) can create dependence



Different days do not guarantee independence. If both days share conditions (weather, flow, observer, habitat), then learning about one day can change probabilities about the other. Independence must be justified by mechanism or design, not by calendar time. Independence has nothing to do with sample size or an event being rare.




In a landscape study 50% of sites are forested (event F, so P(F) = 0.5) and 75% of sites have a stream (event S, so P(S) = 0.75). Among forested sites, 60% have a stream, so P(S | F) = 0.6. What is the probability that a site is forested given that it has a stream?

0.10.70.40.5



You are asked to find P(F | S). So, applying Bayes’ rule:
P(F | S) = [P(S | F) × P(F)] / P(S) = (0.6 × 0.5) / 0.75 = 0.4




What is the name of the rule P(A ∪ B) = P(A) + P(B) − P(A∩B)?



Addition rule.




If P(A) = 0.7, what is the minimum possible value of P(A ∪ B)? HINT: it helps to draw Venn diagrams to come up with solution.



Union contains A, so it cannot be smaller than P(A). Minimum occurs when B is a subset of A.




If P(A | B) > P(A), what does that suggest?

B makes A less likelyA and B must be independentB provides information that increases the probability of AA and B must be mutually exclusive



Knowing B increases the probability that A happens. It does not imply mutual exclusivity, and it contradicts independence.




If P(A) = 0.2 and P(B) = 0.3 and A and B are mutually exclusive, compute P(A ∪ B).



For disjoint events, union is additive: 0.2 + 0.3 = 0.5.




What is the term for events where knowing one occurred does not change the probability of the other?



Independent events means P(A | B) = P(A), equivalently P(A ∩ B) = P(A)P(B).




Which statement is an axiom (always true) in probability theory?

Probabilities must sum to 0 across eventsThe probability of the sample space is 1Probabilities can be negative for rare eventsProbabilities depend on measurement units



One axiom is normalization: if S is the sample space (all possible outcomes), then P(S)=1. Other axioms include non‑negativity (P(A) ≥ 0) and additivity for disjoint events. Units matter for measurements (e.g., °C vs °F), but not for probability axioms.




In words, what does the symbol ∪ mean?



A ∪ B is the union, that is outcomes where either A or B occurs.




Given P(A) = 0.6, P(B) = 0.5, P(A ∩ B) = 0.4, compute P(A ∪ B).



Use addition rule for overlapping events: P(A ∪ B) = 0.6 + 0.5 − 0.4 = 0.7 (subtract overlap once to avoid double-counting).




If P(A) = 0.4, compute P(Aᶜ).



Complement rule: 1 − 0.4 = 0.6.




In a fish survey, event A = “a randomly selected captured fish is female.” If P(A) = 0.40, what is P(Aᶜ)?

0.400.001.400.60



Use the complement rule: P(Aᶜ) = 1 − P(A) = 1 − 0.40 = 0.60.
Interpretation: in the long run, about 60% of captured fish would be non‑female under the same sampling process (not necessarily in every sample).




Which statement is always true for any events A and B?

P(A ∩ B) ≥ P(A)P(A ∩ B) ≤ P(A)P(A ∪ B) = P(A) + P(B) alwaysP(A | B) > 1



The intersection (A∩B) is a subset of A, so it cannot be more probable than A: P(A ∩ B) ≤ P(A). The union equals the sum only when events are disjoint. Probabilities cannot exceed 1.




Given P(A ∩ B) = 0.12 and P(B) = 0.30, compute P(A | B).



Computation: P(A | B) = P(A ∩ B) / P(B) = 0.12 / 0.30 = 0.4.




In a nest monitoring project, event A = “the nest is predated this season.” If P(A) = 0.30, what does the complement event Aᶜ represent?

The nest is presentThe nest is not predated this seasonThe nest is successfulThe predator is absent from the region



Aᶜ is “not A.” So Aᶜ means no predation in that season.
NOTE: “not predated” is not automatically the same as “successful” unless you define success as “not predated” (you might also have abandonment, wildfires, etc.). Clear event definitions matter.




Suppose P(A ∩ B) = P(A). What does this imply about the relationship between A and B?

Whenever A happens, B also happens (A ⊆ B)A and B are independentWhenever B happens, A also happens (B ⊆ A)A and B cannot co-occur



If the intersection equals P(A), then all of A is inside B (i.e., A ⊆ B).
That is, whenever A happens, B must also happen. This is a useful logical interpretation that can appear in ecological event definitions. For example, if A is “juvenile of sockeye” and B is “sockeye”, then A is a subset of B. If you sample a fish and it is a sockeye juvenile, then it is also certainly (i.e., P(B) = 1) a sockeye. It follows that P(A ∩ B) = P(A)P(B) = P(A).




A snorkel survey defines A = “juvenile salmon observed” and B = “water temperature > 20°C at survey time.” Which interpretation is correct?

P(B | A) is the probability juveniles are observed given T > 20°CP(A ∩ B) is the probability juveniles are observed or T > 20°CP(A ∪ B) is the probability juveniles are observed and T > 20°CP(A | B) is the probability juveniles are observed given T > 20°C



P(A | B) reads “A given B.” Here: probability of observing juveniles given temperature exceeds 20°C. Be careful with symbols: ∩ means AND, ∪ means OR (inclusive). This is a common source of mistakes.




In words, what does the symbol ∩ mean?



A ∩ B is the intersection, that is outcomes where both A and B occur.




What is the term for two events that cannot occur together?



Mutually exclusive or disjoint events have no overlap: P(A ∩ B) = 0.




Let P(A) = 0.2 and P(B) = 0.5. Without knowing whether the events overlap or not, what is the largest possible P(A ∪ B)?



Largest union occurs when there is no overlap (disjoint events): 0.2 + 0.5 = 0.7.




Which are valid ways to compute P(A ∪ B)? Select all that apply.

P(A P(B)P(A) + P(B) − P(A ∩ B)1 − P((A ∪ B)ᶜ)P(A) + P(B) if A and B are mutually exclusive



General addition rule subtracts overlap. If disjoint, overlap is 0 so it simplifies. You can also use the complement of the union. The product rule is for intersections under independence, not unions.




What is the name of the rule P(Aᶜ) = 1 − P(A)?



Complement rule.




Which are always true for any events A and B? Select all that apply.

P(A ∪ B) ≥ P(A)P(A ∩ B) ≤ P(A)P(A ∩ B) ≤ P(B)P(A ∪ B) = P(A) + P(B) always



Intersection is a subset of each event, so it cannot be larger than either P(A) or P(B). Union contains A, so it cannot be smaller than A. Union equals sum only when A and B are disjoint / mutually exclusive (i.e., no overlap).




An ecologist says:
“Before I collect new data, I can still assign a probability that a stream reach is occupied by bull trout based on prior surveys and expert knowledge.”
This statement aligns most closely with which definition of probability?

Bayesian: probability cannot be updated with dataFrequentist: probability is the long-run relative frequency of outcomes in repeated trialsFrequentist: probability must be 0 or 1 before data are collectedBayesian: probability represents a degree of belief given current information



The statement is explicitly about assigning probability before collecting new data using existing information and expert knowledge. That is the Bayesian interpretation: probability is a degree of belief conditional on what you currently know.
A frequentist interpretation typically treats probability as a long‑run frequency under repeated identical trials. It does not assign probabilities to fixed but unknown hypotheses (like “this reach is occupied”) in the same way Bayesians do.




If events A and B are mutually exclusive, which statement is true?

P(A | B) = P(A)P(A ∩ B) = 0P(A) = P(B)A and B must be independent



Mutually exclusive means cannot happen together, so the overlap is zero: P(A ∩ B) = 0. They are not independent unless one event has probability 0.




In a salmon smolt study, you estimate P(survive | low flow) = 0.30 and P(survive) = 0.45. Which conclusion is most appropriate?

Survival is lower under low flow than overallLow flow increases survivalThis proves low flow causes mortalitySurvival and flow are independent



Compare conditional to marginal probability: 0.30 < 0.45, so survival appears less likely under low flow than overall. That implies association (dependence). However, it does not prove causation, as high flow could be correlated with other factors (timing, predators, turbidity). Probability comparisons identify patterns, whereas causal claims require mechanistic understanding and stronger design/analysis.




A researcher studying amphibian occurrence samples a wetland in two consecutive days. The probability that amphibians are detected on a daily sample depends on the weather. Which statements could be true? Select all that apply.

If weather conditions persist, P(detect sample 2 | detect sample 1 ) could be higher than P(detect sample 2)Sampling in different days guarantees independenceMutual exclusivity implies you cannot detect amphibians on both sampling daysDetecting amphibians in the two sampling days may be dependent because of weather effects



Shared drivers (i.e., weather in this case) can create dependence across sampling days. Detecting amphibians on the first sampling day due good weather can indicate a high probability of detection on the second sampling day if weather conditions persist. Mutual exclusivity is not appropriate here because detecting in two consecutive days is possible.




Which statements correctly describe complements? Select all that apply.

A ∪ Aᶜ equals the sample spaceA and Aᶜ are independentA and Aᶜ cannot occur togetherP(Aᶜ) = 1 − P(A)



Complements are mutually exclusive (can’t happen together) and exhaustive (one must happen), so their probabilities sum to 1. They are not independent unless P(A) = 0 or P(A) = 1, because knowing A occurred tells you Aᶜ did not occur.




Which statements are consistent with probability axioms (foundational statements) and rules (derivations fom axioms)? Select all that apply.

P(A) can exceed 1 if A is commonProbabilities are non-negativeP(S) = 1 for sample space S (i.e., normalization)P(A) + P(Aᶜ) = 1



Non‑negativity and normalization are axioms. The complement rule gives P(A) + P(Aᶜ) = 1. Probabilities never exceed 1.




If A and B are independent and P(A) = 0.3, P(B) = 0.3, compute P(A ∩ B).



Use product rule: 0.3 × 0.3 = 0.09.




Suppose P(A) = 0.6, P(B) = 0.5, P(A ∩ B) = 0.4. Which statements are true? Select all that apply.

P(A | B) = 0.8A and B are not mutually exclusiveP(A ∪ B) = 0.7A and B are independent



Compute union: 0.6 + 0.5 − 0.4 = 0.7. Independence would require 0.6 × 0.5 = 0.3, not 0.4. Intersection is not 0, so not mutually exclusive. Conditional: P(A | B) = 0.4 / 0.5 = 0.8.




You survey a wetland and estimate that the probability a randomly chosen quadrat contains cattails is 0.65. Which interpretation is most appropriate under the frequentist definition of probability?

Cattails are guaranteed to be present in every wetlandIn the long run, about 65% of randomly sampled quadrats would contain cattailsExactly 65% of all quadrats always contain cattailsThere are exactly 65 cattails per quadrat



A probability like 0.65 describes uncertainty and is often interpreted as a long‑run frequency by frequentists. That is, if you repeatedly sample many quadrats under similar conditions, you would expect cattails in about 65% of them on average. It does not mean you will get exactly 65% in every small sample, it does not describe abundance (how many cattails), and it does not guarantee they will be present in every wetland.




Which statements about conditional probability are correct? Select all that apply.

If independent, P(A | B) = P(A)It can be larger or smaller than the marginal probabilityIt uses information after the word ‘given’It always increases probability



Conditioning can increase or decrease probability depending on association. Independence means that conditioning does not change probabilities.




If P(A | B) = 0.6 and P(B) = 0.5, compute P(A ∩ B).



Multiplication rule for dependent events: P(A ∩ B) = P(A | B)P(B) = 0.6 × 0.5 = 0.3.




In a habitat survey, A = “site is in forest”, B = “site has moss present”. Which statements are plausible? Select all that apply.

P(A ∩ B) ≤ P(A)P(A ∩ B) can be greater than P(A)A and B could be dependent because forest microclimate supports mossA and B must be independent because they are different attributes



Dependence is plausible via dependence of moss on cool and humid microclimates, which can be provided by forests. The intersection cannot exceed either event, so P(A ∩ B) ≤ P(A).




Which conditions imply independence? Select all that apply.

P(A ∩ B) = 0P(A ∩ B) = P(A)P(B)P(B | A) = P(B)P(A | B) = P(A)



The first three are equivalent characterizations of independence (when defined). P(A ∩ B) = 0 is mutual exclusivity, not independence unless one event has probability 0.




In a set of lakes, 40% have high nutrient levels (event N), so P(N) = 0.4. Historically, algal blooms (event B) have occurred in 35% of the lakes, so P(B) = 0.35.
Among lakes with high nutrient levels, 70% have algal blooms, so P(B | N) = 0.7.
What is the probability that a lake has high nutrient levels given that it exhibits an algal bloom?

0.20.80.40.6



You are asked to find P(N | B). So, applying Bayes’ rule:
P(N | B) = [P(B | N) × P(N)] / P(B) = (0.7 × 0.4) / 0.35 = 0.8




A researcher surveying pileated woodpeckers visits the same forest twice. Let A = “woodpecker detected on visit 2” and B = “woodpecker detected on visit 1.” Which statement best describes P(A | B)?

Probability that both occurProbability of B given AProbability that neither occursProbability of A given B



P(A | B) is the probability of A given B occurred.




What is the name of the rule P(A ∩ B) = P(A | B)P(B)?



Multiplication rule.




Why is assuming independence often risky in ecology?

Because probabilities cannot be estimated in ecologyBecause ecological processes are often linked by mechanismsBecause independence violates axiomsBecause independence always reduces probabilities



Ecological variables are frequently connected by causal pathways (temperature ↔︎ DO, habitat ↔︎ survival, predators ↔︎ prey). Independence is a strong simplifying assumption. When it fails, calculations like P(A ∩ B) = P(A)P(B) can be seriously misleading.

title: Lab 01 — Introduction to R
text: The goals of this lab are to introduce you to the basics of using R on RStudio. By the end of this lab, you will be able to:

title: Lab 01 — Introduction to R
section: Step 1 — Create a free Posit Cloud account
text:
Step 1 — Create a free Posit Cloud account

Click here to open Posit Cloud on your browser.
If you do not already have an account:

Click the Get Started button at the center of the main Posit Cloud page or Sign Up on the top right of the page (Figure 1).
On the next page, select a Free account (click on the button Learn more under the Free option, NOT Student account) (Figure 2).
Then, on the next page, click the big Sign Up button (if you selected the Free account option in the previous step you will see cost $0/forever above the Sign Up button) (Figure 3).
On the next page, fill up the required information (username, password, first name, and last name), click Sign up, and follow the instructions to activate your account.


 






Figure 1: Main Posit Cloud page. Red arrows show where you can click to sign up for an account, whereas blue arrows show where to click to login once you have an acccount



 






Figure 2: Account options at Posit Cloud. Make sure to select the Free account by clicking at the Learn more button under Free as indicated by the red arrow.



 






Figure 3: Sign up page for the Free account. After confirming that you picked the Free account by checking that cost is $0/forever click Sign Up as indicated by the red arrow

title: Lab 01 — Introduction to R
section: Step 2 — Log in to Posit Cloud
text:
Step 2 — Log in to Posit Cloud

Go to Posit Cloud in your web browser.
Click Log In (Figure 1).
Enter your credentials.

title: Lab 01 — Introduction to R
section: Step 3 — Create a new RStudio project
text:
Step 3 — Create a new RStudio project

After logging in, you will see your workspace in Posit Cloud. On the far right of the page, click on New Project (Figure 4).
This will open a menu. Now, click on New RStudio Project (Figure 4).
Wait for the RStudio session to launch.
When you see RStudio, double click on Untitled Project (top left) and rename the project to 01 - Introduction to R (Figure 5).

You’re now ready to start learning R in this lab!
 






Figure 4: View of the workspace in Posit Cloud. To start a new RStudio project, click on New Project (red arrow) and then on New RStudio Project (blue arrow)



 






Figure 5: View of an initial RStudio session on Posit Cloud. Make sure to rename the project we will use in this lab as 01 - Introduction to R by double clicking on Untitled Project (red arrow)









Naming matters





We will use consistent project names all term to keep your work organized.

title: Lab 01 — Introduction to R
text:
Step 4 — Install the swirl package
In the Console, run:
install.packages("swirl")






Package installation





You only need to go through this package installation step once within an RStudio project in Posit Cloud. If you need the same package in another RStudio project in Posit cloud, it will need to be installed in that project. However, if you’re using RStudio on your computer, you only need to install a package once and it will be available to be loaded in all projects you create.

title: Lab 01 — Introduction to R
text:
Step 5 — Load the swirl package
In the Console, run:
library(swirl)






Loading packages





All R packages that you install, like swirl, have to be loaded with function library() every time you start a new RStudio session if you plan on using the package. There is a way to automatically load packages you use often whenever you start RStudio, but we will not show that in the course. Just keep in mind that if you’re trying to use a function from a package that you’re certain you have already installed, but get an error that the function doesn’t exist, it’s likely that you forgot to load the package…

title: Lab 01 — Introduction to R
text:
Step 6 — Install the lab exercises
In the Console, run:
install_course_github("eogmartins", "biol325-swirl-labs", multi = TRUE)

title: Lab 01 — Introduction to R
text:
Step 7 — Start swirl
In the Console, run:
swirl()






Interacting with swirl





Every time you start swirl, it will ask your name. Be consistent and always use the same name (e.g., avoid sometimes using your full first name and your nickname at other times - pick one and stick to it) so swirl knows what lessons you already completed.



You should now see an interactive prompt in the R console guiding you through the lab. Once swirl presents you with a list of courses, type the number of the course associated with 01 - Introduction to R (should be 1) and press Enter/Return. You will then be presented with a list of lessons in the course that you must go through (select by typing the number of the lesson in the R console and pressing Enter/Return) in the following order:

Basic Building Blocks
Workspace and Files
Sequences of Numbers
Vectors
Missing Values
Subsetting Vectors
Matrices and Data Frames
Looking at Data
Base Graphics

Once you finish a Lesson, swirl will once again show you a list of courses. Select 01 - Introduction to R and then the next lesson in the list that appears. Then rinse and repeat until you complete all nine lessons in this lab.
When you first run swirl, it presents you with a list of useful commands. You can always see that menu again during the lesson if you execute command info() when you’re are at the prompt (you will know the prompt is waiting for a command if you see > on the far left side of the R console). Below is a screenshot of the list for your reference.






Figure 6: List of helpful swirlcommands

title: Lab 01 — Introduction to R
text:
Step A1 — Install R

Go to the Comprehensive R Archive Network (CRAN).
Choose your operating system (Windows, macOS, or Linux).


NOTE: If you have an older Mac running on Intel processors, you will need the legacy version of R (latest version is 4.2.3)


Download and install the latest version of R using the default settings.

title: Lab 01 — Introduction to R
text:
Step A2 — Install RStudio

Go to the RStudio Desktop download page.
Download the free version of RStudio Desktop compatible with your OS.
Install it using the default settings.

title: Lab 01 — Introduction to R
section: Step A3 — Create a project for this lab
text:
Step A3 — Create a project for this lab

Open RStudio on your computer.
Select File → New Project.
Choose New Directory → New Project.
Name the project: 01 - Introduction to R
Choose a location on your computer where you will keep BIOL 325 course work.
Click Create Project.

title: Lab 01 — Introduction to R
section: Step A4 — Complete the same lab steps locally
text:
Step A4 — Complete the same lab steps locally
Follow the same instructions as described above in Step 4 — Install the swirl package
At this point, everything should be identical to using Posit Cloud.

title: BIOL 325 — Ecological Analyses
text:
Welcome to the website of BIOL 325 — Ecological Analyses at UNBC. This site contains

Lab instructions
Practice lab quizzes
Practice lecture quizzes

Use the navigation bar at the top to select among this material.

title: Lab 02 — Importing & Wrangling Data in R
text:
The goals of this lab are to introduce you to a workflow you will use all term:
After completing this lab tutorial and assignment, you should be able to:
Equiped with these skills, you should be comfortable moving from I have a data file to I have a clean data frame I can analyze.

title: Lab 02 — Importing & Wrangling Data in R
text:
What is an R script?
An R script is a plain text file ending in .R that contains your code (and comments). Scripts are how we conduct reproducible data analysis tasks because they record every step of your analysis, can be re-run later to reproduce results, and make it easier to debug and collaborate. Learn more about R scripts in Chapter 6 of R4DS.






Best coding practices






Start with a header: name, date, purpose
Use clear object names (e.g., penguins_csv, not df1)
Use paths relative to the working directory (e.g., data/penguins.csv), never setwd()
Comment why you did something (not just what)

Comments can be added by using # before any text. R will ignore anything after #.

Use one tidyverse verb per line in pipelines for readability
Use spaces between either side of operators and after commas. For example, do this x <- 5 * y + mean(z, na.rm = TRUE) rather than this x<-5*y+mean(z,na.rm=TRUE)

Learn more about good coding practices in Chapter 4 of R4DS.

title: Practice Quiz - Introduction to R
text:
What is the last number produced by seq(2, 20, by = 3)?



The sequence is 2, 5, 8, 11, 14, 17, 20. Because 20 is exactly reached, it is included.




For m <- matrix(1:6, nrow = 2), what is m[2,2]?



Filled by column, the matrix columns are (1,2), (3,4), (5,6). Row 2, column 2 is 4.




If m <- matrix(1:9, nrow = 3), what is ncol(m)?



The command specifies a matrix with three rows. Since you have nine values to populate a 3-row matrix, it follows that the matrix must have three columns.




Write the indexing expression to get the last element of a vector x.



The last element is at position length(x), so x[length(x)] returns it.




Let x <- c(3, NA, 7). What is sum(x, na.rm = TRUE)?



na.rm = TRUE removes missing values before summing: 3 + 7 = 10.




Which base R function makes a histogram?



hist() is the function that draws a histogram using base R graphics.




Let x <- c(1, 2, 3). What is mean(x)?



The mean is (1 + 2 + 3) / 3 = 2.




If you run x <- c(2, 4, 6), what type of object is x?

a vectora lista data framea matrix



c() combines values into a vector, s x is a vector.




Let x <- 1:10. What is sum(x)?



The sum 1+2+…+10 equals 55.




Let x <- c(10, 20, 30). What is length(x[x > 15])?



Values greater than 15 are 20 and 30, giving a vector of length 2.




Which of these are valid ways to create a numeric vector? Select all that apply.

list(1, 2, 3)c(1, 2, 3)seq(1, 3)matrix(1:3, nrow = 1)



Both c() and seq() create vectors. matrix() creates a matrix (even if 1-row). A list is not an atomic numeric vector.




For x <- c(10, 20, 30), which expressions return 20? (Select all that apply)

x[2]x[1]x[3]x[x == 20]



Index 2 is 20, and logical subsetting x == 20 returns 20. Indices 1 and 3 return 10 and 30.




Which objects are vectors in base R? Select all that apply.

c(1, 2, 3)1:10c("a", "b")matrix(1:6, nrow = 2)



Vectors include numeric/integer/character vectors (e.g., c(1,2,3), 1:10, c("a","b")). A matrix is a different class with two dimensions.




Write the base R function that creates a sequence with a chosen step size (e.g., by = 0.5).



seq() is the function that you can use to create sequences with flexible start/end/step values.




In base R graphics, which function creates a scatterplot?

hist()barplot()plot()boxplot()



plot(x, y) is the standard base R scatterplot function when x and y are numeric vectors. hist() makes histograms, boxplot() boxplots, and barplot() bar charts.




Which expressions create sequences of values? Select all that apply.

seq(1, 9, by = 2)rep(1, 5)1:5seq(1, 5)



1:5 and seq() create sequences. rep() repeats values rather than stepping through a range.




Which base R function returns the number of rows of a matrix m?



nrow() is the function that returns the number of rows in matrix (also works for data frames).




Write a base R expression that creates the integer sequence from 1 to 10 using a :.



1:10 uses the colon operator to create an integer sequence from 1 to 10.




Suppose x <- c("a", "b", "c"). What does x[c(TRUE, FALSE, TRUE)] return?

“b”“a” “b” “c”“a” “c”TRUE FALSE TRUE



Logical indexing keeps elements where the logical vector is TRUE. Here, it keeps elements 1 and 3, returning c("a", "c").




In base R, if you call plot(1:5, 1:5), how many points are plotted?



Both x and y have length = 5, so five points are plotted.




Let x <- seq(0, 1, by = 0.25). How many numbers are produced?



The sequence is 0, 0.25, 0.5, 0.75, 1. That is 5 numbers.




Which of the following are examples of missing values in R? Select all that apply.

NA"" (empty string)NaNNULL



NA is the standard missing value in R. NaN can arise from undefined numeric operations (e.g., 0/0). NULL means “no value” and "" is an empty string, not missing.




You have an RStudio Project with a data/ folder. Which path is portable across computers if you share your RStudio project with a colleague?

penguins.csvC:/Users/Eduardo/Desktop/course/data/penguins.csvdata/penguins.csv/Users/eduardo/Desktop/course/data/penguins.csv



data/penguins.csv is a relative path within the project, so it works as long as the same project structure exists in different computers. Absolute paths (starting with a drive letter or /Users/...) typically break on other computers.




Write the function that changes the working directory.



setwd() is the function that changes the working directory for the current R session.




Write the base R command that reports how many elements a vector x has.



length(x) returns the number of elements in x.




Let x <- c(3, 5, 7, 9). What is length(x)?



A vector with four entries has length 4. length() counts elements, not values.




Let x <- rep(5, times = 6). What is length(x)?



rep(5, times = 6) repeats 5 six times.




Which statement about the R workspace is true?

The workspace is the set of objects currently in memory (Environment).The workspace is a folder on disk that always matches your working directory.The workspace is the same thing as the Console.The workspace is the same thing as your script file.



In R, the workspace refers to objects currently in memory (e.g., vectors, data frames) shown in the Environment tab of RStudio. Files live on disk; scripts are text files; the Console is where commands run.




Which code creates a 2×3 matrix?

matrix(1:6, nrow = 3, ncol = 2)matrix(1:6, nrow = 2, ncol = 3)cbind(1:2, 3:4, 5:6)rbind(1:3, 4:6)



matrix(1:6, nrow = 2, ncol = 3) creates 2 rows and 3 columns, filling down columns by default. The others either have different shapes or build the matrix by binding.




Write a function that lists files in the current working directory in base R.



dir() or list.files() returns a character vector of file and folder names in the current directory (or a specified path).




Which function returns the current working directory?

list.files()getwd()dir.create()setwd()



getwd() returns the current working directory as a character string. setwd() changes it; list.files() lists contents; dir.create() creates a folder.




For m <- matrix(1:6, nrow = 2), what does m[2, 3] return?

5642



The matrix is filled by column: columns are (1,2), (3,4), (5,6). Row 2, column 3 is 6.




What does seq(1, 9, by = 2) produce?

1 2 3 4 5 6 7 8 91 3 5 7 92 4 6 81 4 7



seq(1, 9, by = 2) starts at 1 and steps by 2 until it reaches 9: 1, 3, 5, 7, 9.




Let x <- c(3, 5, 7, 9). What is x[3]?



Indexing with [3] returns the third element of the vector, which is 7.




Write the base R plotting function used for a box plot.



boxplot() is teh function that produces a box plot in base R when given a numeric and a categorical vector.




Which practices help keep your analysis reproducible? Select all that apply.

Hard-coding the working directory assetwd("C:/Users/.../") in scriptsUsing relative paths like data/file.csvKeeping raw data files in a stable folder within the projectUsing an RStudio Project



Projects, relative paths, and stable data locations make it easy to re-run your analyses. Hard-coded paths defined by setwd()are typically not portable between computers.




Which functions are from base R graphics? Select all that apply.

hist()boxplot()plot()ggplot()



plot(), hist(), and boxplot() are base R graphics. ggplot() is from ggplot2.




Write the base R function that returns the current working directory.



getwd() is the function returns the current working directory.




Which approach is most reproducible when reading data in a project?

Storing files in random locations and using absolute pathsClicking Import Dataset in RStudio every timePutting data in a folder named data/ and using relative paths in codeRenaming files each time you run the analysis



Putting data inside a data folder (e.g., data/) nested in the project folder and using relative paths means your analysis can be re-run reliably, shared, and version controlled.




For x <- c(5, NA, 9), what is sum(x) by default?

9NA145



By default, arithmetic with missing values returns NA because the sum is unknown unless you explicitly remove missing values using na.rm = TRUE.




How many elements are in matrix(1:12, nrow = 3)?



1:12 has 12 values. The matrix reshapes them but does not change the total number of elements.




What does x[2] return for x <- c(10, 20, 30)?

10c(20, 30)3020



The command indicates you want teh second element of c(10, 20, 30), so 20 would be returned.




Let x <- c(1, NA, 3). What is mean(x, na.rm=TRUE)?



Removing NA leaves 1 and 3. Mean is (1 + 3) / 2 = 2.




Which are good ways to create a project-relative path to a file such as data/penguins.csv? Select all that apply.

"data/penguins.csv"paste("data/", "penguins.csv", sep = "")file.path("data", "penguins.csv")"C:/Users/name/course/data/penguins.csv"



Relative paths and file.path() are portable. paste() works but can be less robust across OS separators; file.path() is best practice. Absolute paths are not portable.




If list.files() prints 0 filenames, how many files matched your criteria?



An empty result means zero files matched your criteria (or the directory is empty).




In R, the working directory is best described as

the default folder R uses to read/write files unless you it give a paththe folder where your Quarto file is savedthe folder where RStudio stores its settingsthe folder where R is installed



The working directory is the default location for file input/output when you use relative paths (e.g., read.csv("data/file.csv")).




Which statements about matrices in R are true? Select all that apply.

length(m) gives the number of elements in the matrix.Matrices are have a dim attribute.Matrices can be indexed with [row, col].Matrices can contain multiple data types in different columns like a data frame.



A matrix has two dimensions. You can index it with [row, col], whereas length() counts all of its elements. Mixed types per column are not allowed in matrices, only in data frames.




Which calls will return NA without additional arguments? (Select all that apply)

sum(c(1, 2, 3))length(c(1, NA, 3))mean(c(1, NA, 3))sum(c(1, NA, 3))



Summaries often return NA if NA is present unless na.rm = TRUE. length() counts entries including NA, so it returns 3 (not NA).




Which statement best describes why setwd() inside scripts is discouraged?

It prevents using vectors in R.It breaks the Console.It is slower than relative paths.It can silently point to the wrong folder on someone else’s computer.



setwd() hard-codes assumptions about file locations. In a project workflow, you should rely on the project root and relative paths so your code works for others and on other machines.
